Cercospora Leaf Spot.Cause: Fungal disease caused by Cercospora capsici; survives on seeds, residues, and spreads by rain splash and wind in warm, humid conditions.
Cercospora Leaf Spot.Symptoms: Small brown circular spots with whitish or grey centres and dark rings ('frog-eye' pattern) on leaves; yellowing, leaf drop, and sometimes infection on fruit stalks.
Precautions: Use certified disease-free seeds and planting material.
Ensure proper spacing and air circulation; avoid leaf wetness.
Remove and destroy infected plant debris.

Chemical: Spray copper hydroxide, chlorothalonil, or mancozeb at first signs; repeat every 10â€“14 days.
Seed treatment with captan (3 g/kg) helps reduce primary infection.
Organic: Avoid overhead irrigation to reduce leaf wetness.
Mulch soil surface to minimize splash; maintain field hygiene.

Healthy.Cause: No infection or stress present; optimal growth maintained.
Healthy.Symptoms: Dark green, uniform leaves with healthy growth and fruit set.
Precautions: Maintain balanced fertilization and irrigation schedule.
Inspect regularly for early pest or disease symptoms.
Keep tools and nearby fields clean to prevent contamination.

Chemical: No treatment required; maintain preventive schedule during high-risk periods.
Organic: Monthly neem oil spray as preventive protection.
Apply compost or vermicompost to boost soil health.

Murda Complex (Mites & Thrips).Cause: Caused by thrips (Scirtothrips dorsalis) and mites (Polyphagotarsonemus latus) under warm, dry conditions with poor irrigation and high nitrogen use.
Murda Complex (Mites & Thrips).Symptoms: Leaf curling, crinkling, silvery patches, bud drop, stunted growth, and deformed fruits.
Precautions: Maintain spacing and airflow; intercrop with barrier crops like maize or sorghum.
Remove and destroy heavily infested plants.

Chemical: Use abamectin, spiromesifen, or fenpyroximate for mites.
Use spinetoram or imidacloprid for thrips control.
Organic: Spray neem oil or neem seed extract every 10 days.
Use predatory mites or sticky traps for early control.

Nutritional Deficiency.Cause: Imbalance or deficiency of major or micronutrients such as nitrogen, potassium, calcium, magnesium, zinc, or boron.
Nutritional Deficiency.Symptoms: Pale yellow leaves (N deficiency), leaf margin burn (K), blossom-end rot (Ca), or interveinal chlorosis (Mg).
Precautions: Conduct soil testing before planting and fertilize accordingly.
Use balanced fertilization with both macro and micro nutrients.
Avoid overuse of any single nutrient, which can block others.

Chemical: Apply nitrogen, potash, or calcium nitrate as per soil recommendations.
Use foliar sprays of Zn, Mn, or Fe chelates for micronutrient deficiencies.
Organic: Use composted manure to balance soil nutrients.
Apply vermicompost or biofertilizers to maintain microbial health.

Powdery Mildew.Cause: Fungal disease caused by Leveillula taurica, favoured by moderate temperatures, high humidity, and poor air circulation.
Powdery Mildew.Symptoms: White powdery coating on leaves, stems, or fruits; leaf curling and premature leaf drop.
Precautions: Avoid excess nitrogen and overhead irrigation.

Chemical: Spray wettable sulfur (0.3%) or tebuconazole/difenoconazole at early stages.
Repeat fungicide applications as per local guidelines if infection persists.
Organic: Spray diluted milk (1:9 ratio) or neem oil fortnightly.
Maintain canopy hygiene and remove debris.
